title: Taxi driver dad guilty of murdering mum-of-five amid bitter custody battle
text:
Sarah Wellgreen was last seen alive on 9 October 2017 at her home just days before her son’s 12th birthday (Picture: PA)

A taxi driver has been found guilty of murdering the mother of his children amid a bitter custody battle.

Ben Lacomba, 39, was convicted at Woolwich Crown Court today of the murder of missing mother-of-five Sarah Wellgreen, 46, whose body has never been found.

During his trial, jurors were told Lacomba killed Sarah in a ‘calculated manner’.

Sarah was last seen alive at her home in in New Ash Green, Kent, on 9 October, 2017, just days before her son’s 12th birthday.

Ex-boyfriend Lacomba was charged with her murder and accused of hiding her body.

Ben Lacomba has been found guilty of Sarah’s murder (Picture: Jim Bennett)

Sarah’s body has never been found (Picture: PA)

Alison Morgan, prosecuting, told jurors his motivation for the killing was to ‘leave no trace and to remove’ Sarah from ‘his life forever’.

Beautician Sarah had been living a ‘happy life with much to look forward to’ when she disappeared.

She had split from Lacomba in 2014 but they still lived together at their home at the time of her disappearance.

Lacomba showed no emotion as the guilty verdict was read out. He stood in the dock wearing a dark suit, shirt and dark blue tie.

The couple met online in 2004 but by the time of Sarah’s disappearance their relationship was marked by ‘tensions and problems’, the court heard.

Taxi driver Lacomba said he was asleep in bed on the night of the alleged killing.

Ben Lacomba, 39, murdered Sarah and hid her body in an attempt to evade justice, the court heard (Picture: PA)

But prosecutors argued he switched off a CCTV system in the middle of the night and parked his car in an unusual spot in order to evade detection.

Giving evidence during the trial, Lacomba said it was ‘unusual and weird’ when he woke up one morning to find Sarah was not at home.

It took the jury three-and-a-half hours to reach its verdict.

A date for sentencing has yet to be decided.
